Class dom.session.ComponentDObject 

java.lang.Object
    |
    +----dom.session.DObject
            |
            +----dom.session.ComponentDObject
Subclasses:
GenericContainable, GenericContainer
public class ComponentDObject
extends DObject
DObject subclass that allows message handling to be done by 'components' or 'ingredients' that are abitrary java object instances 'owned' by the DObject. This subclass exposes certain methods to the component instances, so that they can send messages to their host/client versions.

Author:
Scott Lewis
Source Code:
ComponentDObject.java

Method Detail

initialize

protected void initialize() throws java.lang.InstantiationException
Initialize this instance. This is called in the DObject constructor, and it allows this subclass to call arbitrary initialization code. The implementation for this class is to do nothing, as all critical initialization is done within the DObject constructor.

NOTE: If subclasses override this method, they should be sure to call super.initialize() in the subclass version of this method. Also, more than likely they should call super.initialize() as the *first* thing in the subclass version

Throws:
java.lang.InstantiationException - can be thrown if some problem with initialization
Overrides:
initialize in class DObject

getStateForClient

protected java.io.Serializable getStateForClient(SessionViewID id)
Get state of this ComponentDObject for delivery to new client. The resulting object must implement the Serializable interface, as it will be sent over the wire to the remote client for initialization. For this class, what this does it to iterate through all of the components making up this ComponentDObject, and call their 'getStateForClient' methods. If a given component returns a non-null object, this object is added to a hashtable of component states, which is serialized, sent over the wire to the new client, and will ultimately be passed to the 'setInitialState' method on the appropriate component.

NOTE: If this method is overridden by a subclass, the subclass should probably also override the 'setInitialState' method below, so that the correct initialization happens for clients.

Parameters:
id - the SessionViewID of the view where the client is being constructed
Returns:
the Serializable object that contains the state to be sent to the new client. This object will be passed into the constructor of the remote client (last parameter) during the construction of the instance.
Overrides:
getStateForClient in class DObject
See Also:
getStateForClient, setInitialState

setInitialState

protected void setInitialState(java.io.Serializable param) throws java.lang.InstantiationException
Set initial state for all our components. This method is called inside the constructor for the DObject instance (host and client), and is passed the Serializable last parameter. If this is a client, the host method 'getStateForClient' determines what the parameter actually is, and is sent over the wire in the construct message. For this ComponentDObject class, the implementation of this is to a) cast the param into a Data object (created by the getStateForClient method above); b) get the (String) component identifier and the Serializable object for initializing that component; c) call the 'setInitialState' method on the the found component, with the found Serializable object for its initial state.

NOTE: If this method is overridden, the 'getStateForClient' method above should probably also be overridden.

Parameters:
params - the Serializable object that is passed to this method by the constructor. For this superclass, the value of params is null.
Throws:
java.lang.InstantiationException - can be thrown if some problem with setting the initial state
Overrides:
setInitialState in class DObject
See Also:
getStateForClient

sendToRemoteComponents

public void sendToRemoteComponents(java.lang.String componentIdentifier,
                                   Closure aClosure) throws java.io.IOException, java.io.NotSerializableException
Send the given closure to the component on all remotes identified by the componentIdentifier parameter.
Parameters:
componentIdentifier - the component identifier used to disambiguate which component to use to process the given Closure
aClosure - the Closure to process
Throws:
java.io.IOException - thrown if Closure cannot be sent
java.io.NotSerializableException - thrown if parameters in aClosure are not serializable

sendToRemoteComponent

public void sendToRemoteComponent(SessionViewID viewID,
                                  java.lang.String componentIdentifier,
                                  Closure aClosure) throws java.io.IOException, java.io.NotSerializableException
Send the given closure to the component on all the *given* remote. Same as above, except that message is only delivered to view specified by first parameter.
Parameters:
viewID - the viewID where this message is destined for
componentIdentifier - the component identifier used to disambiguate which component to use to process the given Closure
aClosure - the Closure to process
Throws:
java.io.IOException - thrown if Closure cannot be sent
java.io.NotSerializableException - thrown if parameters in aClosure are not serializable

Parameters:

aClosure - the Closure to deliver

cmr

public void cmr(java.lang.String componentIdentifier,
                Closure message) throws java.lang.Exception
Method invoked to to message routing to the components that make up this ComponentDObject. Facets wishing to have Closures routed to a component identified by the componentIdentifier should send *this* message to the ComponentDObject instance. This method will be invoked, and the give closure will be invoked on the appropriate component, if found.
Parameters:
componentIdentifier - the identifier for the target component
message - the Closure to actually be executed on the target component
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - thrown if any problem delivering or executing message

getComponentForIdentifier

protected BaseComponent getComponentForIdentifier(java.lang.String identifier)

addComponent

protected void addComponent(java.lang.String identifier,
                            BaseComponent component) throws ComponentException
Add given BaseComponent with given identifier key to our components hashtable. The identifier key must be unique within this ComponentDObject...otherwise a ComponentException will be thrown.
Parameters:
identifier - the String identifier for the given component. Must be unique within this ComponentDObject. If it is not, a ComponentException will be thrown
component - the BaseComponent that we wish to add to our set of components
Throws:
ComponentException - thrown if either of the parameters are null, or if the identifier is already being used.

removeComponent

protected void removeComponent(java.lang.String identifier)
Remove the component with the given identifier. Ignored if component not found.
Parameters:
identifier - the unique identifier (within this ComponentDObject) to remove

otherDeactivated

protected void otherDeactivated(DObjectID otherID)
Message sent from View to us if we have explicitly asked to be registered as a listener for other DObjects via the addDObjectListener call. This message will be sent to us by the View whenever a DObject has been deactivated. Subclasses will probably choose to override this so they can respond to this message, if they call addDObjectListener.
Parameters:
otherID - the DObjectID of the DObject that has been deactivated
Overrides:
otherDeactivated in class DObject
See Also:
addDObjectListener

notifyComponentsOfDeactivation

protected void notifyComponentsOfDeactivation(DObjectID otherID)
Notify all the components that we know about that a DObject with given id has deactivated. This is so that the components that are interested can clean up after themselves.
Parameters:
otherID - the DObjectID of the other DObject that has deactivated.
See Also:
otherDeactivated

receiveCapability

protected void receiveCapability(DObjectFacet aFacet)
Override of DObject.receiveCapability. In this case, whenever we receive a DObjectFacet from another DObject, we just turn around and ask all of the Components that we have if they would wish to cache this facet for later use. They can do whatever they want to do with the facet. This override simply turns around and calls notifyComponentsOfFacet.
Parameters:
aFacet - the DObjectFacet that we have been so kindly given
Overrides:
receiveCapability in class DObject
See Also:
notifyComponentsOfFacet

notifyComponentsOfFacet

protected void notifyComponentsOfFacet(DObjectFacet aFacet)
Notify all the components that a facet from another DObject has been received. This is so the Components can (if they wish) store away the relevant facet for potential later use.
Parameters:
aFacet - the DObjectFacet that has been provided to us
See Also:
checkFacetForCache
